item.title: World Cup hopes shattered as Ireland shocked by Armenia
item.description: Ireland's World Cup dream turned into a nightmare as Heimir Hallgrimsson's side were shocked in Yerevan, losing 2-1 to bottom seed Armenia at the Republican Stadium.

item.title: Minister outlines action plan to tackle rise in bovine TB
item.description: Minister for Agriculture Martin Heydon has outlined the Department's latest plan to tackle the rise in bovine TB, which he described as "the biggest change in our approach in a generation".

item.title: 'Everybody is worried' after strike - Irish woman in Doha
item.description: An Irish woman working in Doha has said that the Israeli strike on the Qatari capital was surreal, frightening and unnerving.

item.title: Man suspected of bringing tear gas to Heathrow arrested
item.description: Police in London have arrested a 57-year-old man suspected of bringing what is thought to be tear gas into Heathrow Airport, causing Terminal 4's check-in area to briefly shut down.

item.title: Martin must own FF decision on Gavin, and any failure
item.description: After much intrigue, former Dublin GAA manager Jim Gavin won the internal Fianna Fáil vote to be its Presidential Election candidate.

item.title: Thousands of starfish in mass stranding at Scottish beach
item.description: A mass stranding that saw thousands of starfish wash up on a beach was most likely the result of heavy seas and strong currents, an expert has said.

item.title: Pope says Israel’s attack on Hamas in Qatar marks a 'very serious situation'
item.description:
While leaving his residence in Castel Gandolfo to return to the Vatican, Pope Leo XIV briefly answered journalists’ questions about the bombing in Doha: “We don’t know where things are headed. We must pray a lot and continue to work and insist on peace.” Regarding the evacuation order in Gaza City and his effort to contact the parish priest there, the Pope said: “I have no news.”

Read all

item.title: World Cup qualifying recap: Armenia 2-1 Ireland
item.description: The Republic of Ireland's World Cup qualifying hopes suffered a huge blow as they slumped to a 2-1 defeat away to Armenia. Here's how it happened.

item.title: Who is Al-Hayya, the top Hamas figure targeted by Israel?
item.description: Khalil Al-Hayya, a senior Hamas official targeted by Israel in Qatar has become a central figure in the leadership of the Palestinian militant group since Ismail Haniyeh and Yahya Sinwar were killed last year.

item.title: Macron seeks new prime minister after govt collapses
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron is seeking his fifth prime minister in less than two years after opposition parties united to oust centre-right Prime Minister François Bayrou over his unpopular plans for budget tightening.

item.title: Macron names loyalist Lecornu as new prime minister
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron named loyalist Sébastien Lecornu, a one-time conservative protégé who rallied behind his 2017 presidential run, as prime minister, defying expectations he might tack towards the left.

item.title: Irish author makes €2.1 million settlement with Revenue
item.description: A top-selling Irish author of young adult books has made a settlement of more than €2.1 million with the Revenue Commissioners for under-declaring income tax.

item.title: India: Thousands celebrate Nativity of Virgin Mary at ‘Lourdes of the East’
item.description:
At the Feast of the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary, millions of devotees flock to Tamil Nadu, India, to venerate the Mother of God over the course of an 11-day annual festival held across major Basilicas and Shrines in the South Indian state.

Read all

item.title: Nepal's PM resigns after violent protests over social media ban, government corruption spread
Ethiopia's new mega-dam promises power, but sparks unease downstream
item.description: Looming high above the Blue Nile and stretching nearly two kilometres across, the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) has been a nation-building project and potential economic revolution 14 years in the making. With its inauguration today, it is officially Africa’s largest hydroelectric project.

item.title: Condemnation after Israel attacks Hamas leaders in Qatar
item.description: Israel has launched an audacious attack on Hamas leaders in Qatar, expanding its military actions that have ranged across the Middle East to include the Gulf Arab state where the Palestinian Islamist group has long had its political base.

item.title: Israel orders Gaza City evacuation
item.description:
Gaza City residents were airdropped Israeli leaflets on Tuesday ordering them to evacuate immediately as the government in Tel Aviv said it was about to obliterate the area in an assault to wipe out Hamas.

Read all

item.title: Hornet seen in beer garden was 'twice the size of a wasp'
item.description: A scientist who spotted a hornet in a beer garden at the end of July, triggering a biosecurity alert for Ireland, has said he knew by looking at it that it was not one of Ireland's native species.

item.title: Ryanair seeks judicial review over night-time flight cap
item.description: Ryanair has applied for a High Court judicial review to challenge a planning decision limiting the number of night-time flights at Dublin Airport.

item.title: Michigan judge tosses case against 15 accused fake electors for President Trump in 2020
item.description: The case has dragged through the courts since Michigan Attorney General Dana Nessel, a Democrat, announced the charges more than two years ago.

item.title: Ethiopia inaugurates Africa’s largest hydroelectric dam
item.description:
Ethiopia officially inaugurates Africa’s largest hydroelectric project.

Read all

item.title: Watch: Students' advice for first years starting college
item.description: Tens of thousands of students are starting college for the first time this month and new beginnings can bring a mix of emotions.

item.title: Six dead in Doha including Qatari security officer
item.description: Follow developments as Israel launches an airstrike against Hamas leaders in Qatar, where the Palestinian Islamist group has long had its political base.

item.title: Former TD admits to driving under influence of cocaine
item.description: A former TD has admitted to driving under the influence of cocaine, after being stopped at a checkpoint in Co Galway, in June 2023.

item.title: MEPs divided over use of 'genocide' in Gaza vote
item.description: A potentially divisive stand-off is re-emerging in the European Parliament over whether to include the word 'genocide' in a vote on the situation in Gaza.

item.title: Energia to increase electricity prices by up to 12.1%
item.description: Energia has announced a price increase of up to 12.1% for its electricity that will add more than €200 onto the annual bills of many customers.

item.title: Peacekeeping: A lifeline for millions seeking a ‘future without fear’
item.description: With a record number of active conflicts worldwide, the Security Council met on Tuesday to debate the future of UN peace operations.

item.title: Nepal PM resigns after deadly crackdown on youth protests; UN urges calm
item.description: Nepal’s Prime Minister resigned on Tuesday following a violent crackdown on youth-led anti-corruption protests left at least 19 dead and hundreds injured, prompting urgent appeals from the United Nations for restraint and dialogue.

item.title: Sudan’s people tortured and killed in ‘slaughterhouses’, rights probe says
item.description: A high-level independent rights probe into the brutal war in Sudan condemned the many grave crimes committed by all combatants, citing evidence indicating that civilians have been “deliberately targeted, displaced and starved”.

item.title: Ukraine: Russian strike on village kills over 20, mostly pensioners
item.description: A Russian airstrike on a Ukrainian village in the frontline region of Donetsk on Tuesday has reportedly killed more than 20 – including many elderly civilians who were lining up to collect pension payments.

item.title: Attacks on schools surge by ‘staggering’ 44 per cent over the past year
item.description: Attacks on schools in conflict zones around the world have increased by a “staggering 44 per cent” over the past year according to the United Nations, resulting in the death, abduction and trauma of thousands of teachers and students.

item.title: Military spending worldwide hits record $2.7 trillion
item.description: Global military spending reached an unprecedented $2.7 trillion in 2024 amid intensifying wars and rising geopolitical tensions worldwide.

item.title: Cote d'Ivoire: Church spearheads initiative for a peaceful election
item.description:
As the presidential election scheduled for 25 October 2025 draws near, the Ivory Coast National Justice, Peace, and Environment Commission, with the Church at its helm, has recently launched a series of public conferences at the Episcopal Conference offices under the theme: 'Ivory Coast, Land of Peace and Hope.' The goal of the discussions is to discourage electoral violence especially since the national political scene seems tense, raising fears of a polarised electoral climate.

Read all

item.title: Ex-SFI chief got €200,000 payout as part of legal deal
item.description: The former Director General of Science Foundation Ireland, Professor Philip Nolan received a payout of €200,000 - plus an additional €275,000 for his legal costs - as part of the settlement of his legal action concerning the termination of his SFI contract in May 2024.

item.title: Diversity carnival against racism to take place in Dublin
item.description: A diversity carnival against racism will take place in Dublin later this month.

item.title: Small number of jobs under threat at TikTok in Ireland
item.description: A small number of jobs are under threat at the Irish operation of video-sharing platform TikTok.

item.title: Loneliness 'powerful factor' in health of older people
item.description: Loneliness has emerged as a persistent and powerful factor influencing the health and wellbeing of older adults, according to Trinity College Dublin's Irish Longitudinal Study on Ageing

item.title: 'Brutally savage' Russian airstrike kills 24 in Ukraine
item.description: A Russian strike has killed 24 people waiting for pension payments in a front-line town of eastern Ukraine where Russian forces are massing forces for a large-scale offensive, officials said.

item.title: Pope Leo: ‘Peace, not conflict, is our most cherished dream’
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV reaffirms the Catholic Church’s commitment to walk the path of peace with other religions, in a message to an interreligious conference in Bangladesh.

Read all

item.title: Trump says Doha strike on Hamas 'does not advance' U.S., Israel goals as Canada, world leaders condemn attack
Hamas says 5 of its members killed, including son of top leader, in Israeli attack in Qatar
item.description: Israel launched a fatal strike targeting Hamas leaders in Qatar on Tuesday as they considered a U.S. proposal for a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip. The strike on the territory of a U.S. ally marked a stunning escalation and risked upending talks aimed at winding down the war and freeing hostages.

item.title: Israel airdrops leaflets ordering Gaza City evacuation, triggering panic among residents
item.description: Palestinians living in the ruins of Gaza City were bombarded with Israeli leaflets on Tuesday ordering them out, after Israel said it was about to obliterate the area in an assault to wipe out Hamas.

item.title: 'Sustainable' measures to help families in Budget
item.description: Tánaiste Simon Harris has said that "sustainable" measures will help under pressure households in next month's Budget.

item.title: At least 24 civilians killed in Russian airstrike in eastern village, Ukrainian officials say
item.description: A Russian airstrike killed 24 civilians at a pension disbursal point in a village in eastern Ukraine, officials said on Tuesday, and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy called on Kyiv's allies to increase pressure on Moscow to end its war.

item.title: Harris 'doing very best to get on with job' after threats
item.description: Tánaiste Simon Harris said he is doing his "very best to get on with my job" after a series of threats were made against him and his family.

item.title: Pope Leo returns to Castel Gandolfo for brief visit
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV returns to the Barberini Palace at Castel Gandolfo on Monday evening for an overnight stay, according to the Holy See Press Office.

Read all

item.title: Islamic State-linked rebels attack funeral in east Congo, killing at least 61 people
item.description: Allied Democratic Forces rebels with machetes and guns have killed at least 61 civilians at a funeral in east Congo, officials said on Tuesday, in one of the deadliest attacks by the Islamic State-linked group in recent months.

item.title: Israeli evacuation order triggers panic in Gaza City
item.description: Palestinians living in the ruins of Gaza City have been bombarded with Israeli leaflets ordering them out, after Israel said it was about to obliterate the area in an assault to wipe out Hamas, causing panic and confusion.

item.title: Epstein 'birthday book' with alleged Trump note released
item.description: Democrats in the US House of Representatives made public a birthday letter President Donald Trump allegedly wrote to sex offender Jeffrey Epstein more than 20 years ago, though the White House quickly denied its authenticity

item.title: 'I didn't see any hope,' says woman who was homeless
item.description: A woman who spent several months living in emergency accommodation has recalled how she "didn't see any hope or light" at the time.

item.title: 'We've done our waiting' - Leitrim school on new building
item.description: Minister of Education Helen McEntee has indicated that she will meet local TDs to discuss long-standing calls for a new school building for one of the biggest primary schools in the northwest.

item.title: Sonas Chief Executive steps down, citing need for reforms
item.description: The Chief Executive of the domestic violence service Sonas has stepped down, citing red tape and a broader need for reform across the sector as reasons for his departure.

item.title: Young anti-corruption protesters oust Nepal PM
item.description: Nepali Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli has been forced to resign by angry young anti-corruption protesters who defied a curfew and clashed with police a day after 19 people died in a first day of protests.

item.title: Activists determined to reach Gaza despite 'drone attack'
item.description: Activists on a Gaza aid flotilla that alleged it was targeted by a "drone attack" off Tunisia overnight has said they remained "determined" to reach the Palestinian territory.

item.title: Gavin named FF candidate, favours removing Triple Lock
item.description: Fianna Fáil presidential candidate Jim Gavin has said that he is in favour of the abolition of the Triple Lock, which requires Ireland to get UN approval if it wants to send Defence Forces personnel abroad as peacekeepers.

item.title: Donohoe warns Govt against once-off measures in Budget
item.description: Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe has warned that the Government must change course in the upcoming Budget and move away from one-off cost of living measures

item.title: Over 2,600 social homes retrofitted last year - report
item.description: A report on the climate action performance of all 31 local authorities has highlighted a broad range of activities to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, lower energy bills and improve living conditions last year.

item.title: Irish construction activity fell last month - AIB report
item.description: Irish construction activity continued to fall last month, according to AIB's latest Construction Purchasing Managers Index.

item.title: Fifth of children in poverty after housing costs - ESRI
item.description: One in five children are living below the poverty line after housing costs are taken into account, according to research from the Economic and Social Research Institute.

item.title: Eldest Murdoch son wins real-life Succession battle
item.description: The Murdoch family has reached a deal that will see Rupert Murdoch's politically conservative eldest son, Lachlan Murdoch, cement control of the family media empire that includes Fox News and the Wall Street Journal.

item.title: WATCH | U.S. Supreme Court rules federal agents can conduct raids in Los Angeles
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump scored a legal win on Monday when the Supreme Court lifted a federal judge’s limits on immigration stops in Los Angeles. Critics warn the ruling could lead to more aggressive ICE raids and indiscriminate arrests.

item.title: Murdoch family settles dispute on control of media assets
item.description: Rupert Murdoch's children have reached a settlement in the legal dispute over control of the right-wing media mogul's companies, News Corp and Fox Corp have announced.

item.title: Labour wins 2nd term in Norway election as populist right makes gains
item.description: Norway's minority Labour Party government won a second term in power on Monday while the populist right achieved its best-ever result, official counts showed, in an election dominated by concerns over rising living costs and wars in Ukraine and Gaza.

item.title: Democrats release Trump's alleged Epstein birthday note
item.description: A note allegedly from Donald Trump wishing late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein happy birthday - and alluding to their "wonderful secret" - has been released by House Democrats, after the US president denied it existed.

item.title: The Catholic Church's 1st millennial saint was a teen who liked video games and computers
item.description: The Catholic Church has just canonized its first saint who wore sneakers, played video games and used computer programming languages to spread the gospel.

item.title: Heathrow terminal 'safe to reopen' after evacuation
item.description: Heathrow Airport has said Terminal 4 is safe to reopen after it had been evacuated earlier today while firefighters responded to a "possible hazardous materials incident".

item.title: Archbishop Gallagher pays tribute to late Nuncio to EU, Noël Treanor
item.description:
At an event promoted by the Embassy of Ireland to the Holy See, Archbishop Paul Gallagher, Secretary for Relations with States and International Organisations, remembers the life and legancy of the late Archbishop Noël Treanor, former Apostolic Nuncio to the European Union.

Read all

item.title: Freight train slams into a bus outside Mexico City, killing at least 10 people
item.description: A freight train sheared a double-decker bus in half at a crossing northwest of Mexico City on Monday, killing at least 10 people and injuring 55, authorities said.

item.title: Montreal senior jailed in the U.K. for trying to smuggle cocaine inside a mobility scooter
item.description: The National Crime Agency said a 71-year-old Canadian who tried to bring cocaine worth $1.2 million into Britain is the latest example of how drug gangs are getting creative with who they use as their mules.

item.title: What's happened to France's government? Why it collapsed and what comes next
item.description: Legislators toppled France's government in a confidence vote on Monday, a new crisis for Europe's second-largest economy that obliges President Emmanuel Macron to search for a fourth prime minister in 12 months.

item.title: Behind the Story: Threats to Harris and France in turmoil
item.description: The IMF "has been mentioned" in France as the country grapples with political fallout amid soaring public debt, a professor of European politics has told RTÉ's Behind the Story podcast.

item.title: Salesman wins €7,500 for discrimination in the workplace
item.description: A salesman from the Travelling Community who was left "disheartened" and quit after he said he overheard the managing director of his new job making remarks about 'pikeys' and 'tinkers' has secured €7,500 in compensation for discrimination in the workplace.

item.title: 'It was terrifying': Heraty recalls storming of orphanage
item.description: Irish aid worker Gena Heraty has spoken of her ordeal following her release from kidnap in Haiti, recounting that kidnappings are "going on all over Haiti" while speaking of her continued efforts to help others.

item.title: Watch: How do local authorities nominate a candidate?
item.description: The nomination window for the upcoming Presidential Election is open until noon on 24 September.

item.title: International Literacy Day: It is the foundation for the digital world
item.description:
As 8 September marks International Literacy Day, UNESCO releases data and information showcasing that being literate enables people to think critically and navigate the “information-rich society and economy in a safe, effective and responsible manner.”

Read all

item.title: French govt ousted as PM Bayrou loses confidence vote
item.description: France's parliament has ousted the government of Prime Minister Francois Bayrou after just nine months in office, leaving President Emmanuel Macron scrambling to find a successor and plunging the country into a new political crisis.

item.title: At least 50 Palestinians killed in Gaza as Israeli strikes intensify
item.description:
At least 50 Palestinians were killed Sunday in Israeli military operations across the Gaza Strip, according to the Palestinian official news agency WAFA.

Read all

item.title: World News in Brief: UN chief condemns Russian attacks on Ukraine, Gaza crisis continues, protecting civilians in DR Congo
item.description: The UN chief has added his strong condemnation of Russian strikes overnight into Sunday targeting Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities which killed dozens – including children – and damaged civilian infrastructure.

item.title: Afghanistan quake: ‘Communities are struggling with basic survival’
item.description: A senior UN aid coordination official in Afghanistan on Monday urged the international community to respond to earthquake victims’ urgent need for support “not only to survive today, but to have the strength to rebuild their lives tomorrow.”

item.title: Leadership of women crucial to UN’s reinvention at 80, says former Assembly President
item.description: Since the creation of the United Nations 80 years ago, only four women have served as President of the General Assembly, where all 193 UN Member States debate the key issues facing the world.

item.title: Guterres strongly condemns terror attack in Jerusalem
item.description: Two Palestinian gunmen opened fire at a bus stop in Jerusalem on Monday, killing at least six people and leaving others wounded, some in a serious condition, according to Israeli authorities.

item.title: UN ready to assist Nepal following deadly protests
item.description: At least 15 people have been killed in Nepal, and over 100 injured, in large-scale youth protests that erupted in the capital and other cities on Monday following a Government ban on social media platforms, amid wider concerns over corruption, inequality and lack of accountability.

item.title: UN rights chief denounces ‘glorification of violence’ and attack on rule of law
item.description: UN rights chief Volker Türk on Monday condemned what he called a worldwide “glorification of violence” which is underway, as well as “coordinated efforts” to undermine fundamental birthrights. “It is time for States to wake up and to act,” he insisted.

item.title: Pope Leo to preside at ecumenical commemoration of modern martyrs
item.description:
Pope Leo will join with representatives of other Churches and Ecclesial Communities on the Feast of the Exaltation of the Holy Cross for an ecumenical ceremony commemorating 21st century martyrs and witnesses of the faith.

Read all

item.title: African women theologians chart new path for a synodal Church
item.description:
Hekima University College in Nairobi, in collaboration with Watawa Wa Taa, hosts the second African Women Theologians Conference, a groundbreaking gathering aimed at amplifying the voices of women in theological scholarship and church leadership.

Read all

item.title: Boko Haram kills dozens in Nigeria attack
item.description:
In the latest wave of violence in Nigeria, Boko Haram militants kill 60 people in the country's northeast, in an area home to residents who had recently returned from a camp for internally displaced persons.

Read all

item.title: Netanyahu warns Gaza City residents to 'leave now'
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has told residents of Gaza City to evacuate as the military stepped up its assault on the Palestinian territory's main urban centre.

item.title: At least 19 killed as police open fire on Nepal protests over corruption, social media ban
item.description: At least 19 people in two cities died on Monday in Nepal's worst unrest in decades, authorities said, as police in the capital fired tear gas and rubber bullets at protesters trying to storm parliament in anger at a social media shutdown and corruption.

item.title: McDonald rules herself out of Presidential Election race
item.description: Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald has ruled herself out of running in the Presidential Election.

item.title: NZ father on the run with children shot dead by police
item.description: A New Zealand father who had been on the run with his three children for nearly four years was shot dead by police after robbing a farm supply store, police have said.

item.title: Shooting attack at Jerusalem bus stop kills 6 people
item.description: Palestinian attackers opened fire on people at a bus stop during the morning rush hour in Jerusalem on Monday, killing six people and wounding another 12, according to Israeli officials. Police said the two attackers were shot and killed by an Israeli soldier at at the scene.

item.title: How an Anishinaabe artist is bringing truth and reconciliation into classrooms with a board game
item.description: When James Corbiere first designed a board game to help his high school students learn about truth and reconciliation, he never imagined it would one day be prepared for classrooms across the country.

item.title: From Hyde to Higgins: Duties and limits of presidency
item.description: Apart from giving a positive impression of Ireland at home and abroad, what exactly does the role of President involve, and what can the incumbent do when they eventually enter the Áras?

item.title: Ukraine 'just the start' of Putin's conquest plans - Merz
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz has warned that Russian President Vladimir Putin's "imperialist plan wouldn't end with the conquest of Ukraine but would rather be just the start".

item.title: Australian woman gets life in prison for fatal mushroom poisoning of in-laws
item.description: Patterson was convicted in July of murdering Don and Gail Patterson and Gail's sister, Heather Wilkinson, with a lunch of beef Wellington pastries laced with foraged death cap mushrooms.

item.title: Rafah will not be used to displace Palestinians - Egypt
item.description:
Egypt’s foreign minister reaffirms that the Rafah border crossing, the only direct link between Egypt and the Gaza Strip, will not be used to displace Palestinians from their land.

Read all

item.title: Ukraine hit by most devastating attack since war began
item.description:
Between Saturday September 6 and Sunday September 7, Russia launched the largest attack against Ukraine since the beginning of the war with a “record number” of drones—over 800—and 13 missiles.

Read all

item.title: UN provides urgent support after ‘massive’ Russian attack across Ukraine
item.description: A baby was among those killed overnight into Sunday during what was reportedly Russia’s largest aerial assault on Ukraine since its full-scale invasion began in 2022.

item.title: Window to prevent famine spreading in Gaza is ‘closing fast’, UN warns
item.description: The narrow window to prevent the spread of famine from northern Gaza to other parts of the Strip is closing fast, the UN Emergency Relief Coordinator said on Sunday.

item.title: Wake the Giant Music Festival in Thunder Bay connects First Nation students to community
item.description: While the Wake the Giant Music Festival has wrapped up for another year, the Wake the Giant movement continues as students at Dennis Franklin Cromarty High School adjust to life in Thunder Bay, Ont. Here's what some of the school's jingle dress dancers shared following their performance at the annual event about moving from the north for school.

item.title: Pope Leo appeals for peace in Holy Land, Ukraine, areas of world marred by war
item.description:
Before leading the recitation of the Angelus prayer with the faithful in Saint Peter's Square, Pope Leo XIV asks everyone to pray constantly for peace in the Holy Land, Ukraine, and all lands plagued by war, emphasizing that "God wants peace!"

Read all

item.title: The Pope at Vatican Family Festival: ‘Your witness is needed'
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV greets Vatican employees and their families at the annual Families Festival in Vatican Gardens on Saturday evening, saying “We celebrate the joy of being family, of being united.”

Read all

item.title: Pope: Saints call us to look to God, make masterpieces of our lives
item.description:
Addressing over eighty thousand faithful filling Saint Peter’s Square on Sunday for the Mass with the canonization of Pier Giorgio Frassati and Carlo Acutis, Pope Leo XIV says the examples of these two young Saints invite all of us, especially young people, to direct our lives upwards to God and make them masterpieces of holiness, service, and joy.

Read all

item.title: South Korea has finished talks with the U.S. to release Korean workers
item.description: A plane will be on its way to bring back the Koreans once administrative procedures are completed, Kang Hun-sik, the presidential chief of staff, said in televised remarks.

item.title: Igor Gouzenko defected 80 years ago. His Cold War-era bravery hasn't been forgotten
item.description: A small gathering at an Ontario cemetery Saturday commemorated the 80th anniversary of the defection of Igor Gouzenko, an event considered by many historians to mark the start of the Cold War.

item.title: Pier Giorgio Frassati, a “True Brother” to be canonized by Pope
item.description:
Testimonies from young members of Catholic Action reveal the enduring relevance of Pier Giorgio Frassati, who called life “joy through suffering,” and showed that peace and hope are born from someone in love, who says “yes” each day to God and to others.

Read all

item.title: Ukraine’s Zelenskyy vows to keep attacking Russian energy
item.description:
Ukraine’s president vows to continue retaliating against Russian attacks on his country’s energy facilities and civilian sites, despite criticism from neighbours Slovakia and Hungary.

Read all

item.title: Gaza is city of “fear, flight and funerals,” says UN official
item.description:
As Israel prepares to push into Gaza City, a UNICEF official warns of the war’s devastating effect on children.

Read all

item.title: Lord's Day reflection: The cost of discipleship
item.description:
As the Church marks the Twenty-third Sunday of Ordinary Time, Fr Luke Gregory reflects on "The cost of discipleship: a call to true commitment"

Read all

item.title: Pope: Seeing with Mary's eyes helps people and cultures walk in peace
item.description:
Pope Leo concludes the 26th International Mariological Marian Congress with a speech in the Paul Audience VI Hall, stressing that the Virgin Mary continues to open doors, build bridges, tear down walls, and help humanity live in harmony amid diversity.

Read all

item.title: From the Black Earth: Roots of the world according to Wangechi Mutu
item.description:
Until September 14, the Borghese Gallery hosts the exhibition "Black Soil Poems" by Kenyan-American artist Wangechi Mutu—an opportunity to explore the shared roots of humanity through contemporary art.

Read all

item.title: Local leadership powers Indonesia’s climate ambitions
item.description: In the heart of Indonesia’s vast tropical landscapes, the province of Riau, known for its rich peatlands and biodiversity, is emerging as a beacon of climate leadership thanks to a new initiative that places local leadership and customary knowledge at the centre of climate action, in line with national policies.

item.title: The night the mountains shook: A doctor on the front lines of Afghanistan’s earthquake
item.description: The first jolt threw Dr. Abdul Mateen Sahak out of bed. The second sent him to his phone. It was right before midnight, last Sunday, and the steep, mountainous valleys of eastern Afghanistan had just been hit by a powerful 6.0-magnitude earthquake, closely followed by the first of many aftershocks.

item.title: First Nation in Manitoba worried for missing woman last seen over 2 weeks ago
item.description: Community members and police are concerned for a missing Wasagamack woman who hasn’t been seen in the First Nation community for more than two weeks.

item.title: Score One for those Blasted Anti-Science Bible Thumpers
item.description: Where do you find a Bible verse posted everywhere? In Berea, where they got it right despite the science of the time.

item.title: Pope at Jubilee Audience: the life of Jesus is the treasure
item.description:
Pope Leo resumes the special Saturday Jubilee Audiences this morning and focuses his catechesis on when Jesus says, "The kingdom of heaven is like a treasure hidden in a field.”

Read all

item.title: Mass stabbing renews plea for heightened support for Manitoba First Nations police, safety officers
item.description: Some Indigenous leaders want more support for First Nations officers to address security gaps after a mass stabbing in a community with no permanently stationed Mounties, policed by an RCMP detachment an hour away by road.

item.title: What does narwhal taste like? In Iqaluit, it's a tasty way to help keep Inuit culture alive
item.description: Organizations in Nunavut are hiring hunters to catch and supply country food, in an effort to tackle rampant food insecurity.

item.title: Musqueam to appeal Cowichan Tribes ruling on Aboriginal title
item.description: The Musqueam Indian Band is the latest government to announce its plans to appeal the recent B.C. Supreme Court decision that found another First Nation government holds Aboriginal title for land and fishing rights in an area of Metro Vancouver.

item.title: Cardinal Parolin: Tragic situation in Gaza, stop the carnage in Ukraine
item.description:
The Cardinal Secretary of State speaks on the sidelines of an event at Rome's Bambino Gesù Hospital. The Holy See continues to raise its voice in the hope that solutions leading to an end to the conflicts can be found.

Read all

item.title: These artists are putting an Indigenous spin on Labubus
item.description: Indigenous artists are making traditional attire for the wildly popular toy collectibles as a way to showcase their craft, connect with their roots and bring a modern twist to old traditions.

item.title: First Nations leaders talk repatriation of cultural items on final day of AFN annual general assembly
item.description: First Nations leaders talked about the need to develop a national repatriation strategy for artifacts, cultural items and ancestral remains at the Assembly of First Nations annual general assembly in Winnipeg on Friday.

item.title: Pope Leo XIV: Caring for Creation is our vocation
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV inaugurates Borgo Laudato si’ at Castel Gandolfo, describing the Village and its project to sustain and nurture integral ecology as a “seed of hope” and a model for ecological conversion.

Read all

item.title: Putin warns foreign troops in Ukraine would be ‘legitimate targets’
item.description:
After European leaders met in Paris to discuss possible security guarantees for post-war Ukraine, Russian President Vladimir Putin warned on Friday that any foreign troops sent to Ukraine would be “legitimate targets” for attack by Russian forces.

Read all

item.title: Mathias Colomb First Nation needs temporary generator, end to wildfire evacuation: chief
item.description: A Manitoba First Nation is pressing the federal and provincial governments to fund a generator that can provide temporary electricity to the remote northern community that's been under an evacuation order for more than 100 days.

item.title: Pope Leo receives Polish President Nawrocki
item.description:
Pope XIV receives in audience the President of Poland. Karol Nawrocki then holds talks with leaders of the Secretariat of State for discussions on the conflict in Ukraine and the socio-political situation of his country.

Read all

item.title: Nordic Bishops hold plenary in Rome, calling for holiness and peace
item.description:
The Nordic Bishops meet in Rome for the plenary assembly to mark the Jubilee Year, joining their voices to the Pope’s call for an end to war, for justice, and for a more missionary Synodal Church.

Read all

item.title: A fourth generation nuclear survivor’s push for justice
item.description: Standing behind the United Nations rostrum on the International Day Against Nuclear Tests, Oemwa Johnson, one of the younger members in the room, called on the General Assembly to heed a growing global call for nuclear justice.

item.title: Amid escalating attacks in Gaza, UN rights chief calls on US to withdraw sanctions against Palestinian rights groups
item.description: Sanctions imposed by the United States on three prominent and well-respected Palestinian human rights groups are “completely unacceptable and should be withdrawn”, UN human rights chief Volker Türk said on Friday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Afghanistan quake latest, sexual violence in Haiti, WHO medicines update, deadly floods in Pakistan
item.description: The UN aid coordination office, OCHA, has released $10 million in response to the urgent need for food, water, shelter and other lifesaving provisions following this week’s devastating earthquakes and aftershocks in Afghanistan.

item.title: UN chief hails ‘remarkable example’ of Papua New Guinea as he concludes historic trip
item.description: Speaking to journalists in the capital of Papua New Guinea (PNG) on Friday, UN chief António Guterres rounded off the first ever visit to the Pacific nation by a sitting Secretary-General, paying tribute to the country’s unbroken 50-year run as a multilingual democracy – which is now beset by major economic and environmental challenges.

item.title: ‘A war of atrocities’ – UN human rights investigators warn Sudanese civilians are paying the highest price
item.description: As the nearly 30-month-long conflict in Sudan between rival militaries grinds on, looting, burning, and shelling continues to destroy livelihoods and hope.

item.title: DR Congo crisis: Funding cuts curtail assistance to victims of sexual violence
item.description: Sexual violence is rife in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), but urgently needed assistance for survivors has had to be halted as sweeping funding cuts bite, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, warned on Friday.

item.title: The missing half: The urgent need for more women’s representation in the media
item.description: Women make up half of the world’s population but receive only 26 per cent of media coverage, according to the latest UN-backed Global Media Monitoring Project (GMMP) report, the world’s largest study on gender representation in news media.

item.title: Air pollution is on the rise – but not everywhere, says UN weather agency
item.description: As billions continue to breathe polluted air that causes more than 4.5 million premature deaths every year, UN climate experts on Friday highlighted how damaging microscopic smoke particles from wildfires play their part, travelling halfway across the world.

item.title: Holy See warns against ‘aggressive nuclear rhetoric’
item.description:
Marking the International Day Against Nuclear Tests, the Holy See’s Permanent Observer to the United Nations stresses the moral duty to support affected communities and to advance toward a world free of nuclear weapons.

Read all

item.title: Pope invites Mediterranean Youth Council to be signs of hope
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV encourages members of the Mediterranean Youth Council to be signs of hope, saying their “high ideals and creativity” allow them to make fundamental contributions to peace in the Mediterranean region and around the world.

Read all

item.title: IAEA Director General: We must stem trend toward nuclear proliferation
item.description:
After meeting with Pope Leo XIV, Rafael Mariano Grossi, Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, speaks to Vatican News about the urgency of slowing the rush toward nuclear rearmament and proliferation.

Read all

item.title: Future Blessed Eduard Profittlich was ‘Estonian by the blood he gave’
item.description:
Ahead of the beatification of Archbishop Eduard Profittlich in Estonia, Bishop Philippe Jourdan and the diocesan postulator share the joy of the Catholic community in the Baltic nation, saying his life bears witness to God’s invitation to faith and peace.

Read all

item.title: Haudenosaunee traditional practices offer tips for back to school stress
item.description: Some say traditional medicines and practices can help parents and students ease into the new school year.

item.title: Students share advice for those moving to Thunder Bay, Ont., from remote First Nations
item.description: As students at Thunder Bay, Ont.'s all-Indigenous high school get settled in the city, faculty and community leaders are running a number of orientation events to help them make the transition. Here's what those at Thursday's Amazing Race event had to say about moving hundreds of kilometres from home to complete high school.

item.title: IN PHOTOS | Who's been seen at TIFF this year
item.description: The 50th Toronto International Film Festival kicked off on Sept. 4. Many Hollywood stars are expected to be in Toronto over the 11-day festival, including Angelina Jolie, Keanu Reeves, Sydney Sweeney and Dwayne Johnson.

item.title: First Nations leaders reiterate need for own policing services at AFN general assembly
item.description: Discussions on systemic racism in policing, and the need to create more First Nations police services was a major focus of the second day of the Assembly of First Nations (AFN) annual general assembly in Winnipeg.

item.title: Wiikwemkoong artist Daphne Odjig celebrated with commemorative $2 coin
item.description: The coin featuring a central design based on her artwork The Folk Singer begins circulating Thursday.

item.title: 'Pray for them': chief says he knew victims of Hollow Water mass stabbing
item.description: Chief Larry Barker talks about the victims of the mass stabbing on Hollow Water First Nation and asks that people pray for them. An 18-year-old was killed and seven others were injured early Thursday morning, RCMP say. The suspect, Tyrone Simard, 26, is also dead.

item.title: Pope to Joint Working Group: Unity amid divided world
item.description:
Archbishop Flavio Pace, Secretary of the Dicastery for Promoting Christian Unity, offers a summary of the plenary session of the Joint Working Group between the Catholic Church and the World Council of Churches (WCC) and their meeting with Pope Leo.

Read all

item.title: ⓜ Full Moon-th Meetup with Rev. Richard A. D’Souza – September 7, 2025
item.description: Join us on Sun. Sept. 7th for a chat with Rev. Richard A. D'Souza - the new director of the Vatican Observatory!

item.title: Archbishop Saure denounces silence on enforcing court order over Church land
item.description:
Mozambique's Archbishop of Nampula, Inacio Saure, on Wednesday, 3 September, denounced the illegal occupation of Church land and spoke out strongly against the lack of action on squatters by authorities despite a court order.

Read all

item.title: The ‘unthinkable’ is underway in Gaza City, UNICEF warns
item.description: The UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) called on Thursday for the international community to do everything possible to prevent catastrophe in Gaza City as Israel ramps up military operations ahead of a planned full takeover.

item.title: Downpours stymy aid teams following deadly landslide in war-torn Sudan
item.description: War-torn Sudan continues to face “a horrific humanitarian situation” as UN colleagues scramble to help communities affected by the devastating landslide that struck Tarseen village in South Darfur state over the weekend, UN Spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric said on Thursday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Afghanistan quake update, Guterres in Papua New Guinea, Ebola returns to DR Congo, UN condemns attack on peacekeepers in South Sudan
item.description: As the death toll from the Afghanistan earthquake disaster jumped to more than 2,200 on Thursday, UN agencies continued to help, while calling for funding to help build sturdier housing to withstand future shocks.

item.title: UN rights office alarm over escalation in Gaza City, annexation plans for West Bank
item.description: A senior official from the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said on Thursday he was extremely concerned over intensifying Israeli military operations in northern Gaza – including Gaza City – and warned against any attempt to annex parts of the West Bank.

item.title: Pope to Israeli President: Urgent ceasefire and aid for Gaza
item.description:
During a private audience, Pope Leo XIV and Isaac Herzog discuss the need for an urgent ceasefire and unimpeded aid access for Gaza, as well as the liberation of all remaining hostages and a two-state solution as the only path to peace.

Read all

item.title: Pope sends prayers and condolences for victims of Lisbon accident
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV expresses his closeness to the victims of the accident that took place in Lisbon on Wednesday, which left at least 17 people dead and others injured.

Read all

item.title: Woman killed by brother in mass stabbing on Manitoba First Nation, RCMP say
item.description: An 18-year-old woman was killed and the suspect — her brother — is dead after multiple people were stabbed in Hollow Water First Nation on Thursday, RCMP say.

item.title: Fr. Faltas on Gaza: ‘It’s truly an inhumane situation'
item.description:
During a visit to Italy, Franciscan friar Ibrahim Faltas illustrates the terrible situation the people of the Holy Land region are living in, and warns that if things continue as they are, “there will truly be no Christians left.”

Read all

item.title: News from the Orient – Sept. 3, 2025
item.description:
In this week's news from the Eastern Churches, produced in collaboration with L'Œuvre d'Orient, Christians refuse to leave Gaza City, the Armenian Catholicos recalls fallen heroes, and nuns from the Middle East take a break in France.

Read all

item.title: Fort Providence woman stressed during evacuation as she waits for gov't financial relief
item.description: As the N.W.T. government sorts through financial aid applications from residents displaced by wildfires, one Fort Providence woman says waiting hasn't been easy.

item.title: Three people share what brings them to AFN assembly
item.description: Winnipeg welcomes representatives from more than 630 First Nations for the Assembly of First Nations annual general assembly.

item.title: Xatśūll First Nation hopes to overturn court ruling on controversial Mount Polley mine
item.description: Xatśūll First Nation lost a bid to stop the height of a tailings dam from being increased at the Mount Polley mine, site of a catastrophic dam collapse in 2014.

item.title: Borgo Laudato si’: Pope Leo XIV to launch new ecological and spiritual chapter
item.description:
The Management Director of the Borgo Laudato Si’ ecology project illustrates the initiative, which Pope Leo XIV will officially inaugurate on Friday, explaining that it is open to everyone regardless of faith or other affiliations. He hopes that tourists visiting the once-exclusive summer Papal Villa, gardens, and farm in Castel Gandolfo will leave inspired by the message of caring for our common home, the Earth.

Read all

item.title: 6 million children will be out of school by 2026 due to funding cuts
item.description:
The UN's agency for children reports funding for education will see a 24% decrease from 2023, which will raise the number of out-of-school children to 278 million or the equivalent of emptying every primary school in Germany and Italy combined.

Read all

item.title: Faithful in Brazil venerate relic of Carlo Acutis in Campo Grande
item.description:
The relic is a dark blue pullover sweater—one of the most well-known garments associated with the young Italian, as he is seen wearing it in several photos. The relic arrived on September 1st at São Sebastião Parish for the canonization of Carlo Acutis scheduled 7 September at the Vatican.

Read all

item.title: Finding strength amid sleepless nights: Ukraine’s hidden mental health toll
item.description: Nearly four years into Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and 11 years since conflict began, the toll on mental health across the country is severe.

item.title: World News in Brief: Pakistan floods, countries lag on climate reporting, concern over attack on peacekeepers in south Lebanon, cuts hit human rights investigations
item.description: Secretary-General António Guterres said on Wednesday he was “profoundly saddened” by the death and destruction caused by the recent floods in northern Pakistan. The current death toll stands at over 400.

item.title: ‘Reparatory justice’ key to ending racism against Africans and their descendants
item.description: Governments, academia and other stakeholders must “double down on delivering reparatory justice” for people from the African diaspora, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said in a report published on Wednesday.

item.title: Attacks across Gaza intensify amid fear and hunger: ‘Leave me here,’ injured girl told fleeing family
item.description: Thousands of Palestinians have been caught in the crossfire while trying to escape attacks and dire food shortages in war-torn Gaza, with extraordinary challenges for some, according to latest reports from UN officials on the ground and the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

item.title: Guterres hails Papua New Guinea as an example of diversity, dialogue and climate action
item.description: The Pacific Island nation of Papua New Guinea is proof that embracing differences can be the world’s greatest strength, the UN Secretary-General said in a speech to parliamentarians in the capital, Port Moresby, on Wednesday.

item.title: Gaza: With a suitcase for a school bag, classrooms have become shelters
item.description: “Instead of studying in school, we’re living in it,” said Diana, summing up the conditions faced by thousands of children in the Gaza Strip whose lives have been turned upside down by war who now face the prospect of a third year without education.

item.title: Pope Leo XIV appeals to international community to respond to crisis in Sudan
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV launches an appeal to the international community to provide humanitarian aid for the suffering people in war-ravaged Sudan, and asks for prayers for those affected by devastating mudslides in the country’s Darfur region.

Read all

item.title: Pope at Audience: ‘I thirst’ is Jesus' cry for love and relationship
item.description:
At the weekly General Audience, Pope Leo XIV reflects on Jesus’ final words on the Cross, and recalls that human fragility “is a bridge towards heaven.”

Read all

item.title: Vatican to host seminar on “Creation, Nature, Environment for World Peace”
item.description:
The meeting will take place 11-12 September at the Casina Pio IV at the Vatican and will be opened by Cardinal Pietro Parolin. The event is organized by the Council of Higher Studies of the Pontifical Academy of Theology, with the participation of ecclesial, business, social, and cultural experts worldwide.

Read all

item.title: Assembly of First Nations annual general assembly begins in Winnipeg
item.description: First Nations chiefs and delegates from across the country are gathering in Winnipeg for the Assembly of First Nations annual general assembly starting Wednesday.

item.title: 'Like watching Gretzky play hockey:' Colleagues remember actor Graham Greene
item.description: Colleagues and friends say Graham Greene was a multi-faceted actor, portraying serious and comedic roles alike, who was "like an uncle" to younger performers.

item.title: Palestinian Foreign Minister: ‘Peace is possible and justice can prevail'
item.description:
A meeting with Holy See officials was on the agenda at the tail-end of a humanitarian and diplomatic tour to several European nations for the Palestinian Minister of Foreign Affairs this week. During her days in Rome, she made time to visit Palestinian children receiving treatment in Italian and Vatican Hospitals.

Read all

item.title: CELAM Theological Center presents Pan-American ecosystem project
item.description:
Last week, a member of the Theological Center presented the initiative, called "Together", to the Pope, explaining that it offers training and practical programs on synodality for the Pan-American region in various languages.

Read all

item.title: 2026 Vatican Observatory Astrophoto Calendars
item.description: Vatican Observatory 2026 Astrophoto Calendars Are Now Available!

item.title: Archbishop Gallagher stresses need for dialogue and rebuilding consensus
item.description:
On the final day of the Bled Strategic Forum taking place in Bled, Slovenia, the Holy See's Secretary for Relations with States and International Organisations, Archbishop Paul Richard Gallagher, underscores the need for dialogue and consensus building in an increasingly divided world.

Read all

item.title: Pope's September prayer intention: For our relationship with creation
item.description:
In his prayer intention for September 2025, Pope Leo XIV invites us to pray that we might experience our interdependence with all creatures, who are loved by God and worthy of love and respect.

Read all

item.title: Cooling La Niña could be back, but global temperatures set to rise: WMO
item.description: The cooling climate phenomenon known as La Niña could return between now and November, but it won’t stop the trend for warmer global temperatures caused by human activity, UN weather experts said on Tuesday.

item.title: Afghanistan quake: Aid teams still scrambling to reach survivors
item.description: In remote eastern Afghanistan, aid workers are continuing to race to assist survivors of Sunday’s devastating earthquake as the death toll continues to climb, UN humanitarians said on Tuesday.

item.title: Funding cuts could push 6 million more children out of school, warns UNICEF
item.description: Global education funding is facing sharp reductions that could leave an extra six million children out of school by 2026, the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) warned on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Open broadcasters were reportedly asked to censor reaction to Trump. Fans still booed
Guterres condemns detention of more UN staff in Yemen
item.description: UN Secretary-General António Guterres has strongly condemned the arbitrary detention of at least 11 staff members in Yemen on Sunday by the de facto Houthi authorities in areas under their control.

item.title: Teachers are the ‘guardians of our future’, says UN deputy chief
item.description: In every corner of the world, educators are making choices that echo across generations – influencing everything from the preservation of forests to the writing of poetry, the building of bridges to the holding of peaceful elections.

item.title: Latin America and Caribbean: Millions more children could face poverty due to climate change
item.description: Climate change could push at least 5.9 million more children and young people in Latin America and the Caribbean into poverty by 2030 unless governments act now.

item.title: Pakistan floods leave villages cut off as monsoon devastation continues
item.description: Relentless monsoon rains continue to wreak havoc across Pakistan, leaving villages cut off, homes destroyed and families struggling to access food, clean water and medical care.

item.title: Iraq unveils historic migration plan to boost development and stability
item.description: Iraq has taken an historic step with the launch of its first ever national migration plan, designed to promote safe, orderly and regular pathways for Iraqis returning home and around 370,000 migrants living and working inside the country.

item.title: Apply for the 2026 ACME Workshop!
item.description: Applications for the Vatican Observatory Foundation's 2026 ACME workshop will be accepted during September

item.title: Stateside: Monday, Aug. 25, 2025
item.description: April Baer interviews Br. Guy Consolmagno for the Stateside podcast.

item.title: One in four still lacks access to safe drinking water and sanitation
item.description: Despite progress over the past decade, billions worldwide still lack access to safe drinking water, sanitation, and hygiene, leaving them vulnerable to disease and social exclusion, according to a UN report released on Tuesday.

item.title: Grad student Rebecca Dudley’s summer studies included an audience with Pope Leo XIV
item.description: Rebecca Dudley was one of 25 students who attended the 2025 Vatican Observatory Summer School.

item.title: Putting water management at the centre of the climate change fight
item.description: Some 2.2 billion people worldwide still lack access to safely managed drinking water services, according to the World Health Organization (WHO) - an increasingly urgent challenge as demand for safer access to the vital resource grows.

item.title: News Wrap: Zelenskyy marks Ukraine’s Independence Day with ceremonies in Kyiv
item.description: In our news wrap Sunday, Ukraine marked 34 years since declaring independence even as its war to repel Russian invaders stretches on, desperation to reach food aid is hitting a new high in Gaza, Israel struck targets in Yemen in retaliation for Houthi attacks, the Pentagon is reportedly planning to deploy troops to Chicago, and 120 teams competed in an international corgi race in Lithuania. PBS News is supported by - https://www.pbs.org/newshour/about/funders. Hosted on Acast. See acast.com/privacy

item.title: Tombs of the Unknown Scientists (re-run)
item.description: In the “Holy Land” of Kentucky stands a monument to a man who cared for and buried the victims of a cholera epidemic, and who might have done some science.

item.title: Aristarchus Plateau emerging
item.description: When the moon is about 12 days past new a dramatic region can be found on the terminator just north of the equator emerging from its long night. It is...

item.title: Guterres in Japan: ‘Humanity is strongest when we stand as one’
item.description: World Expos are not just feel-good exhibitions, “they are invitations to tell our stories,” The UN chief told festival goers in Osaka, Japan, which is hosting Expo 2025.

item.title: Momentum builds towards marine biodiversity treaty, as experts convene in New York
item.description: Delegates from around the world met at UN Headquarters in New York this week to advance the long-awaited high seas biodiversity treaty, with discussions ranging from rules of procedure, to the creation of a clearing-house mechanism and the location of the treaty’s secretariat.

item.title: UN agencies warn of rising heat stress risks for workers worldwide
item.description: Extreme heat is fast becoming one of the biggest threats to workers’ health and livelihoods, the World Health Organization (WHO) and World Meteorological Organization (WMO) warned on Friday.

item.title: Monsoon floods kill more than 700 in Pakistan, with heavy rains set to continue
item.description: Heavy monsoon rains and flash floods have killed at least 739 people across Pakistan since late June, displacing thousands and destroying homes and crops, with more severe weather expected in the weeks ahead, according to UN agencies and national authorities.

item.title: From the Vatican Observatory Faith and Science pages (Younger Readers) — How I got to NASA (the Charles F. Bolden, Jr. story)
item.description: From the Faith & Science Resource Center (Younger Readers): How Charles F. Bolden, Jr. came to pilot the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit and be NASA’s head.

item.title: Fr. Richard D’Souza named Director of Vatican Observatory | The Society of Jesus
item.description: Pope Leo XIV has appointed Fr. Richard D’Souza, SJ as Director of the Vatican Observatory. Fr. D’Souza has been a staff member at the Observatory since...
